Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: An HOA inspection is scheduled and items left in the corridor could be cited for blocking an emergency exit.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I was on my headset, trying to keep my voice calm as the customer on the other end grew more agitated. “You people always call at the worst times! How do I know this offer is even real?” he snapped. I glanced at the clock—just ten minutes until the HOA inspection. My neighbor, Mrs. Lee, had left her potted plants and a shoe rack in the corridor again. If the inspector saw them, we’d both get cited for blocking the emergency exit. As a neighbor, I was expected to be considerate, maybe even help her move the items, but as a telemarketer, I couldn’t just hang up. My supervisor expected me to handle every objection, answer every question, and never let a call drop. My heart pounded as I tried to explain the offer’s legitimacy, but my mind kept drifting to the hallway, picturing the inspector’s clipboard and Mrs. Lee’s worried face. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which demand to answer first.
